item.item: Color of the aleurone or pericarp
Proportion of awns falling off prior to harvest. Taken at maturity
Surface roughness characteristic of the awn
ROUGH (BARBS OVER ENTIRE LENGTH OF AWN)
Presence or absence of awns or hoods on the spike
AWNED ON PRIMARY ROWS - AWNLETTED ON LATERAL ROWS
AWNED ON PRIMARY ROWS - AWNLESS ON LATERAL ROWS
HOODED ON PRIMARY ROWS, AWNLETTED ON LATERAL ROWS
Adherence of the lemma and palea to the caryopsis
Lemma, hull cover, awns and straw at maturity colours
Estimated amount of plant lodging near maturity (1 = NO LODGING 9 = 100% LODGED)
Estimated amount of neck or straw breakage at maturity
IRREGULARE 2 AND 6 CHARACTERS ON THE SAME SPIKE.
ROW MIXED FOR SPIKE ROW NUMBER
Tendency of the kernels to sprout in the spike before harvest as a result of a late rainfall
Color of cotyledon after harvest and cleaning
Color of hypocotyl taken one to two weeks after emergence
Color of leaves taken after flowering or initial pod set but prior to plant senescence
General botanical description for the simple and compound leaf types
No anthocyanin - stems and leaves pale green
No anthocyanin - stems and leaves green
Low anthocyanin - stems and leaves partly light purple
High anthocyanin - stems and leaves predominantly purple
Relative leaf size compared against a standard cultivar and relative within each years planting
Seed coat color after harvest and cleaning
Seed size in weight per 100 seeds. Measured in grams and rounded to the nearest tenth of a gram
General terms of Indian origin used to separate the two basic chickpea types
Type and extent of the awns
Type and extent of glume pubescence
Type and extent of leaf pubescence
Estimated amount of shattering at maturity
Shape characteristic of typical mature spikes
Estimated amount of straw breakage at maturity
Estimated amount of plant lodging near maturity (1 = NO LODGING 9 = ALL PLANTS FLAT)
Grain Type, classes according to USDA grading standards for brown rice
SHORT-GRAIN (AVG. LENGTH: 5.50 mm OR LESS) (AVG. LENGTH/WIDTH RATIO: UP TO 2.1)
LONG-GRAIN (AVG. LENGTH: 6.61 - 7.50 mm) (AVG. LENGTH/WIDTH RATIO: OVER 3.0)
OTHER (NOTE UNDER REMARKS IF EXTREMELY SMALL BOLD, SLENDER, ETC.
Hull color (Lemma and Palea) when terminal spikelets are ripened
HAIRS ON LEMMA KEEL ONLY (CALIFORNIA SMOOTH)
HAIRS ON BOTH LEMMA AND PALEA KEELS (SIDES GALBROUS)
Estimated amount of plant lodging near maturity (1-9 0-10%)
Panicle type classified according to their mode of branching, angle of primary branches, and spikelet density
Culm Angle - rice direct-seeded in rows
Color of sterile lemma - often called outer glumes or bracts at the base of the spikelet
The accession has been tentatively identified as possessing aromatic characteristics at flowering time or when cooked
Kernels free of Barley Stripe Mosaic Virus, based on visual and ELISA evaluations
Reaction to Leaf Rust (incited by Puccinia hordei) in the seedling stage
IMMUNE - NO UREDIA OR OTHER INDICATIONS OF INFECTION.
NEARLY IMMUNE - NO UREDIA BUT A FEW HYPERSENSITIVE FLECKS PRESENT.
VERY RESISTANT - UREDIA MINUTE - SURROUNDED BY DISTINCT NECROTIC AREAS.
MODERATELY RESISTANT - UREDIA SMALL TO MEDIUM - USUALLY GREEN ISLANDS SURROUNDED BY A CHLOROTIC/NECROTIC BORDER.
MODERATELY SUSCEPTIBLE - UREDIA MEDIUM - COALESCENCE INFREQUENT - NO NECROSIS BUT CHLOROTIC SPOTS MAY BE PRESENT.
VERY SUSCEPTIBLE - UREDIA LARGE AND OFTEN COALESCING - NO NECROSIS BUT CHLOROSIS MAY BE PRESENT.
Reaction to Stripe Rust (incited by Puccinia striiformis)
HIGHLY RESISTANT - NO LESIONS OR SIGNS OF DISEASE VISIBLE
RESISTANT - LESIONS VISIBLE BUT MUST LOOK CLOSLEY AT THE PLANT TO SEE THEM
MODERATELY RESISTANT - A FEW LESIONS EASILY VISIBLE
HIGHLY TOLERANT - MANY LESIONS VISIBLE BUT LESIONS HAVE NOT CAUSED IRREPARABLE DAMAGE.
TOLERANT - LARGE LESIONS ON STEMS OR LEAVES, SOME LEAF AND STEM GIRDLING, BUT PLANT WILL NOT DIE
MODERATELY SUSCEPTIBLE - MANY LARGE LESIONS ON STEMS AND LEAVES, MODERATE STEM AND LEAF GIRDLING, PLANT PROBABLY WILL NOT DIE
SUSCEPTIBLE - MANY LARGE LESIONS ON STEMS AND LEAVES, STEM AND LEAF GIRDLING COMMON, PLANT MAY OR MAY NOT DIE BUT WILL PRODUCE SEED
HIGHLY SUSCEPTIBLE - LARGE LESIONS ON STEMS AND LEAVES COMMON, STEM AND LEAF GIRDLING COMMON, PLANT WILL PROBABLY DIE BUT WILL PRODUCE A FEW SEED
HIGHLY SUSCEPTIBLE - INFECTION SEVERITY SUCH THAT PLANT WILL DIE, BUT MAY PRODUCE A FEW SEED
Susceptible to naturally occurring Ascochyta blight
Chickpea Wilt incited by Pea Streak Carlavirus
Exhibits allelopathic activity with radius of reduced weed growth greater than 10 centimeters
LEAVES ARE FLAT - NO APPARENT ROLLING
Russian Wheat Aphid virus reaction index
PLANTS APPEAR HEALTHY - MAY HAVE SMALL ISOLATED CHLOROTIC SPOTS
5% LEAF CHLOROTIC - CHLOROTIC SPOTS BECOME MORE NOTICEABLE
15% LEAF CHLOROTIC - CHLOROTIC SPOTS ARE LARGER AND MORE NUMEROUS.
25% LEAF CHLOROTIC - SOME STREAKING MAY BECOME APPARENT - ESPECIALLY ALONG TH EMIDRIB.
40% LEAF CHLOROTIC - CHLOROTIC SPOTS BEGIN TO COALESCE OR DEFINITE STREAKING OCCURS.
55% LEAF CHLOROTIC - LARGER CHLOROTIC SPOTS COALESCE. LEAVES START TO (DIE-BACK) FROM TIPS.
85% LEAF CHLOROTIC - EXTENSIVE CHLOROSIS AND NECROSIS.
PLANT DEATH OR NO RECOVERY POSSIBLE
MIXED FOR RESISTANCE TO RUSSIAN WHEAT APHID
Reaction to Cereal Leaf Beetle (Oulema melanopus), based on larval feeding damage
Reaction to Straighthead, a physiological disease resulting in malformed panicles
SEVERE DAMAGE WITH PLANTS NOT HEADING
Seedling infection types produced by Puccinia graminis f.sp. tritici
MOSTLY IMMUNE, NO UREDIA - BUT NUMEROUS HYPERSENSITIVE FLECKS PRESENT
IMMUNE - NO UREDIA OR OTHER INDICATIONS OF INFECTION
NEARLY IMMUNE - NO UREDIA BUT A FEW HYPERSENSITIVE FLECKS PRESENT
VERY RESISTANT - UREDIA MINUTE - SURROUNDED BY DISTINCT NECROTIC AREAS
MODERATELY RESISTANT - UREDIA SMALL TO MEDIUM - USUALLY GREEN ISLANDS SURROUNDED BY A DECIDEDLY CHLOROTIC/NECROTIC BORDER
MODERATELY SUSCEPTIBLE - UREDIA MEDIUM SIZE COALESCENCE INFREQUENT - NO NECROSIS - BUT CHLOROTIC AREAS MAYBE PRESENT
VERY SUSCEPTIBLE - UREDIA LARGE AND OFTEN COALESCING - NO NECROSIS BUT CHLOROSIS MAY BE PRESENT
HETEROGENEOUS - UREDIA VARIABLE - SOMETIMES INCLUDING ALL INFECTION TYPES AND INTERGRADATIONS ON THE SAME LEAF
Reaction to Powdery Mildew (incited by Erysiphe graminis f.sp. Tritici). Rated at Feekes growth stage GS 10.3
0 to < 1% leaf area affected on any leaf
1-50% leaf area affected on fourth leaf
> 15% leaf area affected on flag leaf
1-5% leaf area affected on third leaf
5-15% leaf area affected on third leaf
> 15% leaf area affected on third leaf
1-5% leaf area affected on second leaf
5-15% leaf area affected on second leaf
> 15% leaf area affected on second leaf
1-5% leaf area affected on flag leaf
5-15% leaf area affected on flag leaf
Reaction to Leaf Rust (incited by Puccinia triticina). scale 0-9
Reaction to Leaf Rust (incited by Puccinia triticina) in the adult plant stage, measured on the flag leaf
FACULTATIVE TYPE MIXED WITH SOME SPRING TYPES
FACULTATIVE TYPE MIXED WITH SOME WINTER TYPES
SPRING TYPE MIXED WITH SOME FACULTATIVE TYPES
SPRING TYPE MIXED WITH SOME WINTER TYPES
WINTER TYPE MIXED WITH SOME FACULTATIVE TYPES
WINTER TYPE MIXED WITH SOME SPRING TYPES
Growth habit of plants recorded at podding stage
Relative plant size compared against a standard cultivar and relative within each years planting
Plant height measured from the soil surface to the tip of extended panicles
Number of days from effective seeding date until 50% of main tillers show panicles at least partly emerged from boot
Natural life span of species represented by the accession
The accession has been tentatively identified as adapted to upland, non-flooded culture
Concentration of flowers on the plant at just prior to pod formation or at 75% flowering
Hypocotyl color taken after crook stage
Intermediate pinks and may have other colors
Basic Pod color. refers to lighter color when more than one color exists. data taken during pod filling stage but prior to the initiation of defoliation
Pod Pattern - describes distribution of darker color over lighter basic pod color. if only one color, then pattern is classified as uniform
Observation of the general position distribution of the pods. data taken at the middle of the pod filling stage
Some fibrous roots and some tuberous roots
Seed coat, eye or hilum colour
Cleistogamous: Flowers self-pollinate before the blossum opens. Every flower produces seed.
Needs to be hand or sib pollinated with another's pollen
Flowers self-pollinated, but not all flowers produce seed.
Needs to be tripped to pollinate itself
Seed Luster or Brilliance taken on dry seeds recently harvested
2- Points - 2 small points of color at one end of hilum
Anabip - small darker blotch(es) surrounding or at either end of hilum
Amibigua - large (non-uniform) dark blotch nearly covering light color of seed coat
Anasazi - a distinct pattern of large colored blotches, more dark than light
Large and small blotches irregularly distributed
bipunctata pattern - two small markings - one on either end of eye (hilum)
Expansa with fibula arcs - nearly uniformly dark with narrow light bands near hilum
Marginata - small linear darker blotch around hilum
Piebald - a distinct pattern of colored blotches similar to the appaloosa horse pattern, more light than dark
Sellatus - one large darker blotch around the hilum
Virgarcus - the traditional "soldier-shaped" pattern of dark on light
Weak virgarcus - a weakly expressed form of the above
Basic shape seed, regardless of seed size
Refers to the distribution of the darker color over the lighter one on the standard
Spot at base of standard - behind stigma tube
Stripes or dashes in the central area
No host group (Resistant Gene bc-1.2 - bc-2)
Describes architecture of plant through some characters: terminal meristem growth,number of nodes on the stem,internode length,climbing ability,Branching pattern
Indeterminate prostrate or vining but not climbing
Slight injury (little curling or rolling of leaves)
Medium injury (curling or rolling of leaves)
Heavy injury (curling or rolling of leaves - stunting and slight yellowing of leaf edges)
Very heavy injury (curling or rolling of leaves - stunting and severe yellowing of the leaves)
no disease symptoms and completely healthy
between 0-10% leaf surface area showing disease symptoms
10% leaf surface area showing disease symptoms
between 10-25% leaf surface showing disease symptoms
25% leaf surface area showing disease symptom
about one third surface area showing disease
50% leaf surface area showing disease symptoms - and severely stunted
more than half leaf area diseased - but not dead
Resistance to Halo blight (Pseudomonas syringe pv. phaseolicola)
Race differentiation in Pseudomonas syringae pv. phaseolicola
Ur-1 gene confer resistance unknown - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-10 gene confer resistance to 16(moderate resistant) of 87 races - Landrace group is Andean
Ur-11 gene confer resistance 86 of 87 races - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-12 gene confer resistance to 59 of 87 races - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-14 gene confer resistance to 87 of 87 races - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-2 gene confer resistance unknown - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-3 gene confer resistance to 43 of 87 races - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-4 gene confer resistance to 30 of 87 races - Landrace group is Andean
Ur-5 gene (a block of UrA UrB UrC Urd UrE Urf UrG UrG) confer resistance to 68 of 87 races - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-6 gene confer resistance to 15 of 87 races - Landrace group is Andean
Ur-7 gene confer resistance to 8 of 87 races - Landrace group is Middle American
Ur-8gene confer resistance to 15 of 87 races - Landrace group is Andean
Ur-9 gene confer resistance to 75(moderate susceptible) of 87 races - Landrace group is Andean
invasion of the stem past the site of inoculation but not to the first node
invasion of the stem to the first node
invasion of the internode slightly past the first node
invasion to the middle of the internode
invasion slightly past the second node
invasion to the middleof the second internode and beyond
Determination of presence of anthocyanins in the hypocotyl at the 2 to 3 leaf stage of the seedling
Cotyledon color observed in seeds less than 3 months old
Ground color of testa observed on seeds less than 3 months old
Pattern of testa observed on seeds less than 3 months old
COMPLEX.COMBINATION OF DOTTED - SPOTTED OR MARBLED PATTERNS
Coded for ranges of average weight of 100 randomly chosen seeds in grams per 100 seed
To be observed during pod filling stage
Resistance to Pea Enation Mosaic virus
No visual symptoms expressed - plant vigorous
Plant infected - slight yellowing and stunting symptoms - enation present
Plant infected - moderate yellowing and stunting symptoms - enations pronounced
Plant infected - severe yellowing and stunting
Plant infected - plant dead or dying
Determination of relative plant size based on a set of 1-2 selected standards
The color and pattern of the aleurone
Color of the hard endosperm layer
Colored silk scar is not present
Arrangement of kernel rows from the base to the tip of the ear
The color and the pattern of the pericarp. The first number is the color, the second number is the pattern
Shape of the upper surface of the kernel
Tolerance to sulfonylurea herbicides which are acetolactate synthase inhibitors. Qualifier identifies specific herbicide from this group
(2) (0 = NO SYMPTOMS OBSERVED 9 = SEVERE DISEASE DEVELOPMENT)
(3) (0 = NO SYMPTOMS OBSERVED 9 = SEVERE DISEASE DEVELOPMENT)

Plant response to common smut organism (Ustilago zeae(Beckm.) Unger = U. maydis (DC.) Corda))
VERY FEW PLANTS WITH SMALL GALLS.
FEW PLANTS WITH MODERATE SIZED GALLS.
MODERATE NUMBER OF GALLS - SOME LARGE.
MANY PLANTS INFECTED - MOST GALLS LARGE.
MOST PLANTS INFECTED - LARGE GALLS - SEVERE INJURY.
Stalk response to diplodia stalk rot organism (Diplodia maydis (Berc.) Sacc.)
LESS THAN 16% OF INOCULATED INTERNODE ROTTED 1 MONTH AFTER INOCULATION.
Leaf response to eyespot organism (Aureobasidiumzeae (Narita and Hiratsuka) J.M. Dingley = Kabatiella zeae Narita and Hiratsuka)
Moderate number of lesions per leaf below ear.
Numerous lesions on leaves below the ear - but no evidence of lesion coalescence.
Numerous lesions with some killing of patches of leaf tissue below the ear.
Whole leaves killed up to the ear and some disease evident above the ear.
Heavy disease over whole plant - some leaves above the ear severely infected.
Heavy disease over whole plant and some leaves above the ear killed.
All leaf tissue above ear nearly completely diseased.
Leaf response to gray leaf spot caused by (Cercospora zeae-maydis Tehon and E.Y. Daniels)
Plant response to stewart's wilt organism (Erwinia stewartii (Smith) Dye )
Limited spread with water-soaking - chlorosis - or necrosis withiint 3 cm.
Limited spread predominately toward tip end of leaf only.
Abundant spread bi-directionally in inoculated leaves only.
Minimal systemic infection as small, linear streaks on non-inoculated leaves.
Moderate systemic infection with 5-25% symptomatic leaf area on non-inoculated leaves.
Abundant systemic infection and stunting with 25-50% symptomatic leaf area on non-inoculated leaves.
Severe systemic infection and stunting with 50-90% of the plant infected.
90-100% infection - severe necrosis - or dead plants.
Resistance to the European corn borer
(2) Partial Ristance. Little shot-hole lesions on several leaves
(3) Partial Resistance. Several leaves with shot-hole lesions.
(4) Intermediate response. Several leaves with shot-hole lesions and elongated lesions
(5) Intermediate response. Several leaves with elongated lesions.
(6) Susceptible. Several leaves with elongated lesions about one-inch
(7) Mostly susceptible. Long lesions on half of the leaves
(8) Mostly susceptible. Long lesions on two-thirds of the leaves
(9) Mostly susceptible. Long lesions on most all leaves
(2) Feeding scars - but no roots eaten off.
(3) One to several roots eaten off within 1-1/2 inches.
(4) One ring or node of roots completely destroyed.
(5) Two rings or nodes of roots completely destroyed.
(6) Three rings or nodes of roots completely destroyed.

(SS) Belongs to stiff stalk combining group.

Resistance to Downy Mildew (Peronosclerospora sorghi). Based on using 15 plants for each PI
Response of Sorghum Downy Mildew (SDM) to the causal pathogen Peronosclerospora sorghi - pathotype 3 (P3) - metalaxyl-resistant population
No Sorghum Downy Mildew (SDM) reading possible
Resistant - no systemic Sorghum Downy Mildew (SDM) and no local lesion
Susceptible - systemic Sorghum Downy Mildew (SDM) and/or positive for local lesions
Resistance to Gray Leafspot (Cercospora sorghi ELL. & EX.)
Necrotic mosaic but not causing plant death
Plant death due to necrotic mosaic
(2) Resistant [1 = Resistant (0 to 10% leaf damage) 9 = Susceptible (death of the plant)]
(3) Resistant [1 = Resistant (0 to 10% leaf damage) 9 = Susceptible (death of the plant)]
(4) Resistant [1 = Resistant (0 to 10% leaf damage) 9 = Susceptible (death of the plant)]
(5) Resistant [1 = Resistant (0 to 10% leaf damage) 9 = Susceptible (death of the plant)]
(7) Intermediate [1 = Resistant (0 to 10% leaf damage) 9 = Susceptible (death of the plant)]
Flowering rating taken 65 days after planting and approximately 90 days after planting
Very insensitive - headed out, seed produced
Insensitive - very late maturity, seed produced
Less sensitive - several heads but limited seed produced
Sensitive - few heads - no seed production
Accessions crossed to various male-sterile (A-lines) lines in order to test their ability to restore fertility in F1 hybrids within a particular cytoplasmic system
F1 progeny are all male sterile - the parent line is a maintainer (B-line)
F1 progeny fall in between PB and PR in scale5
F1 progeny have between 1-10% seed set - the parent line is a partial maintainer (PB-line)14
F1 progeny have between 50-80% seed set - the parent line is a partial fertility restorer (PR-line)
F1 progeny are all male fertile - the parent line is a restorer (R-line)
Ovate-lanceolate (arrowhead shape - long taper from petiole)

Position of mature fruiting pods relative to peduncle
Crowder - seed flat on both ends
Semicrowder - seed flat on one end and rounded on other
Noncrowder - seed rounded on both ends

Optical properties of cross sectional flesh color of cooked root samples. Translucent samples appear water soaked with the light moving into the sample giving a 3 dimensional appearance. Opaque samples display a 2 dimensional appearance

Plant type taken at growth stages 5-6
Vine growth rate taken at growth stage 5
Textural properties of cooked roots subjectively categorized

Root sweetness determined using sensory analysis by two trained panelists. Sweetness perceived and concentration of sugars does not always coincide since other compounds present in the cooked roots can modulate the perception of sweetness

Estimate of visible root fibers not dietary fiber. Slight ranking has visible fine hair-like fibers only 1 or 2 mm in length. Extensive ranking has long strands of fiber which would definitely decrease the palatability of the sample

Seed type based on seed phenotype and coded as Common Market Class
Alubia - very large - elongate white beans
Carioca - cream colored with brown stripes
Dark red kidney or DRK-type beans
Dumosus (cultivated or piloy bean - a native name for such)
Flor de Mayo or FM-type beans
Kablanketi - large - rounded beans - light colored with tiny purple spots
Market gather (collector obtained from native market)
Navy class or small - round white beans
Seed color (of seed testa) at maturity
Testa color of mature seeds stored no longer than 5 months
Moderate on base and tip of petioles
Wing and Standard petal has pigmented margin
Wing pigmented petal has light V-shape pattern
Wing has pigmented upper margin - standard petal pigmented
Wing is pigmented - Petal is lightly pigmented
Wing is pigmented - Petal is lightly pigmented
Pattern of pigmentation on green pod
E10:Small eye.Eye encircles the back of hilum(H.) in a narrow ring:widens slightly at the sides of H. - extends in a straight band at either sides of H.
A60:the eye fills the narrow groove all around the hilum. similar to Kabba (K) group but no specks on body. flower pigment pattern is 1.
A20:line by hilum (H).straight:narrow band of pigment on each side of H: similar to E10 but pigment does not extend completely behind H.
A40:small hilum ring. similar to N40 but eye more restricted in front of hilum.flower pigment pattern is 1.
W30:Watson blotched.Large blotches of pigment from eye move onto body
W35:Watson speckled. Speckling tends to occur in blotches
N41:Hilum ring:specks similar to N40 but with specks distributed uniformly over body.
E30:Small eye-large. similar to E10: but eye at sides of the hilum is wider than that of E10.
E58:Broad eye:spotted keel.similar to E40 but with spotted keel.
H60:holstein 60 to 80l. Pigment extends out in front of hilum from the large eye and covers 60-80% of the seed.
W31:Watson blotched:dilute.blotches are much less pronounced. Flowering pigment pattern is 4
W55:Watson: nearly self colored. Eye covers almost entire seed except for small portion of micropylar end.
K10:Densely speckled. speckles uniform over body
A70:eye starts in a groove at either side of the hilum and spills out slightly in front of it. flower pigment pattern is 1.
K20:Lightly speckled. speckles uniform over body
N80:Hilum ring:speckled keel. similar to N40 but with specks predominantly on keel.
H28:Large eye: spoted keel: dilute. Similar to H18 but with flower pigment pattern 1
H11:Large eye. Heart shaped eye: with indentation at front of hilum
H40:holstein 40 to 60.pigment extends out in front of hilum from the large eye and covers 40-60% of seed
W15:Watson with dark or speckled body
N40:Narrow Eye(Hilum ring).Eye fills the narrow groove(G.) around hilum(H.) - spills out of this G in front of the H for a short distance and presents an indistinct margin in front
E50:Broad eye. eye is triangle:with the hilum inside: the front of the hilum resting on the base of the triangle.
W20:Watson dilute.The margin in front of the hilum becomes more restricted
H80:holstein 80 to 95. Pigment extends out in front of hilum from the large eye and covers 60-80% of the seed.
K30:Very Lightly speckled. speckles uniform over body
A42:limited hilum ring. similar to A40. differentiated definitely by crossing.
N84:Hilum ring:lightly speckled keel. similar to N80 but with specks less dense.
A81:A thin line of pigment starts at back of the hilum (h) and moves along each side of it. A narrow clear space found b/w eye and H. Flower pigment pattern is 6.
A85:similar to A81 but body is dark.
H48:holstein 40 to 60:spotted keel. Similar to H40 with splashes of pigment on keel joining with the pigment of the eye
H18:Large eye: spotted keel. Similar to H11 but with spotted keel
H29:Very Large eye. a large semi-circle of pigment almost covering each half of the seed: with the center of the beans of each semi-circle at the hilum
K10:densely speckled. speckles uniform over body
H20:Large eye: dilute. Similar to H11 but with flower pigment pattern 1
H30:Large eye to holstein.similar to H11 but splashes of pigment spilling over in front of hilum: the splashes having a distinct margin
A41:restricted hilum ring. similar to A40 but flower pigment pattern is 3.
H38:Large eye to holstein.spotted keel. similar to H30 but with splashes of pigment on keel.
A61:Similar to A60 but flower pigment pattern is 5.
Black spots with mottling on tan
Speckling on brown with clear areas
brown splash on body: tan eye
Brown splash on body: black eye
Speckling on tan with clear areas:as though speckles had erased with random strokes
Solid brown with speckling on tan
Speckling on orange with clear areas
Black spots with speckling on tan
Speckling on red with clear areas
Brown splash on body: mottled eye
Bblack spots with mottling on red
Gray body with brown splash: black eye
Speckled with clear areas and mottling on buff
Solid brown with speckling on red
Speckled with clear areas and mottling on orange
Brown splash on body: red eye
Black with light spots of tan
Black with light spots of red
Short - slightly longer than it is wide
Very Short - Length equal to Width
Intermediate - twice as long as wide
Long - thrice as long as wide
Very Long - at least four times as long as wide
Intermediate - thickness slightly less than the width
Very Flat - thickness half the width
Non-crowder:no compression at all in pod
Extreme crowder:seed so compressd that width is greater than length
Light/Moderate:2 or 3 spots/leaf, on few leaves
Light:scattered spots - no more than 1 per leaf - on more than half the leaves
Moderate:2 or 3 spots/leaf, on most of the leaves
Light:scattered spots - no more than 1 per leaf - on more than half the leaves
Light/Moderate:2 or 3 spots/leaf - on few leaves
Moderate:2 or 3 spots/leaf - on most of the leaves
Severe:Heavy spotting on most leaves with yellowing
Moderate/Severe: heavy spotting on a few leaves
Light/Moderate:2 or 3 spots/leaf - on few leaves
Light:scattered spots - no more than 1 per leaf - on more than half the leaves
Severe:Heavy spotting on most leaves with yellowing
Moderate:2 or 3 spots/leaf - on most of the leaves
Moderate/Severe: heavy spotting on a few leaves
Leaflet size of fully expanded leaves on the lower flowering nodes
Pod dehiscence one week after maturity
Density of spikelet in middle 3rd of main axis
Color of dorsal side of grain
Culm diameter of basal internode at reproductive
LONG (>2.5 MM BUT SHORTER THAN THE LEMMA)
Variety group - Asian, based mainly on the morphologic features
The presence and distribution along the panicle
Seedling vigor. Taken at 15 days after sowing in upland culture
Rate of recovery after the 1st stress. Taken 1 or 2 days after rewatering
